title: Comic Magazines Are Standard Diet
creator: Decatur Herald and Review
description: Newspaper photograph showing two young boys reading comics in front of a newsstand. The caption reads, "Typical outlet for the thousands of magazines bought each month in Decatur is this stand in Tolly's Market on East Wood street. The magazine business is booming and Managers Ray Cohen of Decatur News and R.L. Hackett of American News agencies keep close watch on stands such as this. In fact they can tell you what each neighborhood is reading."
subject: newsstands;news stands;distribution;sales;readers

title: Launch All-Out War on Crime Comics
creator: Southtown Economist
description: Newspaper photograph showing a group of formally attired women standing in front of a table of comics and magazines. The caption reads, "Examples of crime-horror books which deprave the minds and twist the moral values of young people ate viewed at the first meeting of the Citizens Committee for Better Juvenile Literature by, left to right, Mrs. Robert V. Johlic, chairman; Mrs. Ida Marie Cohen, Illinois Council on Motion Pictures, Radio, Television and Publications; Mrs. Joseph Hector, Illinois Federation of Women's clubs; Mrs. Donald Conn, executive board of Citizens committee and director at large of Illinois council; Mrs. Jean Coulter, Citizens committee corresponding secretary, and Mrs. B. A. Levinson, secretary-treasurer. Goal of the group is to hait distribution of the vile publications."
subject: censorship;citizens group;women's clubs

title: County Fairground Loafers
creator: Rock Island Argus
description: Newspaper photo showing a group of boys reading comics. The caption reads, "Caught loafing and reading comic books in one of the tents at the Rock Island County fairgrounds yesterday afternoon were, left to right, Wayne Krouse, 13, Pre-emption, Bob Rogers, 16, Campbell's island: Jim Davis, 12, Milan; Billy Pearson, 11, Edgington; Bill Gustafson, 15, Coal Valley: Ned Nice, 14, Milan; and John Olson, 13, Buffalo Prairie. (Argus photo.)"
subject: readers

title: [Louise Crutcher's Library]
creator: Chicago Defender (National)
description: Newspaper photo that accompanied article about Louise Crutcher, a Black 13-year-old and sophomore at DuSable High School. She started a lending library, which now has 1,500 books and comics in it. Crutcher distributed the books to 'crippled children' for free on Saturdays and was provided 175 comic books by the boxer Joe Louis.
subject: readers;African American;Black;civic engagement;libraries

title: Humboldt Park (0219) Activities - Day camps, 1951
description: Photograph of a young boy in a swimming pool, reading a issue of Haunt of Fear #8, July/August 1951.
subject: readers;horror;EC;Entertaining Comics
source: Chicago Public Library Special Collections & Preservation Division

title: Play Capes Made in Decatur
creator: Decatur Herald and Review
description: Newspaper photograph, accompanying a story, of two boys wearing Captain Marvel Play Capes. The caption reads, Kenneth Kiley of 974 West King street helps his playmate, Jim Schooley of 1024 West View street, adjust a 'Captain Marvel Play Cape.' The capes are a product of the recently organized B & C Manufacturing & Sales Co. of Decatur."
subject: readers;merchandise;manufacturing;toys;Fawcett Comics
